ojc.ahni.experiments

Class TestTargetFitnessFunction

  • java.lang.Object
    • ojc.ahni.integration.BulkFitnessFunctionMT
      • ojc.ahni.hyperneat.HyperNEATFitnessFunction
        • ojc.ahni.hyperneat.HyperNEATTargetFitnessFunction
          • ojc.ahni.experiments.TestTargetFitnessFunction
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Configurable, java.io.Serializable, AHNIEventListener, BulkFitnessFunction

    public class TestTargetFitnessFunction
extends HyperNEATTargetFitnessFunction
    A test fitness function that determines fitness based on how close the output of a network is to a target output given some input. The specific test set can be specified with the property key "fitness.function.test.type". Valid values are:
    • pass-through: the output should match the input.
    • pass-through-flip: same as pass-through except the target output is a mirror of the input.
    • rotate90: the target output is the input rotated 90 degrees.
    • parity: bitwise parity over all inputs.
    • [More to come!]
    The number of trials is determined by the width and height of the input layer as 2 ^ (width + height), thus every possible input pattern is tested. See HyperNEATTargetFitnessFunction for other available parameters that may be specified via the properties file.
    Author:
    Oliver Coleman
    See Also:
    Serialized Form

      • scale

        protected void scale(int scaleCount,
         int scaleFactor)
        Description copied from class: HyperNEATFitnessFunction
        Allow sub-class to make the necessary changes when a substrate scale occurs. If implemented, then at a minimum this method will usually need to set new values for the HyperNEATFitnessFunction.width and {#link height} array fields, and the HyperNEATFitnessFunction.connectionRange field if applicable.
        Overrides:
        scale in class HyperNEATFitnessFunction
        Parameters:
        scaleCount - A count of how many times a scale has previously occurred. In the first call this has value 0.
        scaleFactor - The amount the substrate is being scaled by.
